permissions.description:
Allows an application to read the user's contacts data.

Protection level: dangerous

Allows an application to initiate a phone call without going through the Dialer user interface for the user to confirm the call.

Protection level: dangerous

Allows a regular application to use android.app.Service#startForeground Service.startForeground.

Protection level: normal

Allows applications to discover and pair bluetooth devices.

Protection level: normal

Allows access to the vibrator.

Protection level: normal

Allows an application to record audio.

Protection level: dangerous

Allows an application to write to external storage.

Note: If both your minSdkVersion and targetSdkVersion values are set to 3 or lower, the system implicitly grants your app this permission. If you don't need this permission, be sure your targetSdkVersion is 4 or higher.

Starting in API level 19, this permission is not required to read/write files in your application-specific directories returned by android.content.Context#getExternalFilesDir and android.content.Context#getExternalCacheDir.

If this permission is not allowlisted for an app that targets an API level before android.os.Build.VERSION_CODES#Q this permission cannot be granted to apps.

Protection level: dangerous

Allows an app to access precise location. Alternatively, you might want ACCESS_COARSE_LOCATION.

Protection level: dangerous

Allows an app to access approximate location. Alternatively, you might want ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION.

Protection level: dangerous

Allows applications to open network sockets.

Protection level: normal

Allows an app to use device supported biometric modalities.

Protection level: normal

Allows applications to access information about networks.

Protection level: normal

Allows using PowerManager WakeLocks to keep processor from sleeping or screen from dimming.

Protection level: normal

Allows applications to access information about Wi-Fi networks.

Protection level: normal

Allows an app to use fingerprint hardware.

Protection level: normal Deprecated. Applications should request android.Manifest.permission#USE_BIOMETRIC instead

Allows an application to modify global audio settings.

Protection level: normal

Required to be able to access the camera device.

This will automatically enforce the uses-feature manifest element for all camera features. If you do not require all camera features or can properly operate if a camera is not available, then you must modify your manifest as appropriate in order to install on devices that don't support all camera features.

Protection level: dangerous

Allows an application to read from external storage.

Any app that declares the WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE permission is implicitly granted this permission.

This permission is enforced starting in API level 19. Before API level 19, this permission is not enforced and all apps still have access to read from external storage. You can test your app with the permission enforced by enabling Protect USB storage under Developer options in the Settings app on a device running Android 4.1 or higher.

Also starting in API level 19, this permission is not required to read/write files in your application-specific directories returned by android.content.Context#getExternalFilesDir and android.content.Context#getExternalCacheDir.

Note: If both your minSdkVersion and targetSdkVersion values are set to 3 or lower, the system implicitly grants your app this permission. If you don't need this permission, be sure your targetSdkVersion is 4 or higher.

This is a soft restricted permission which cannot be held by an app it its full form until the installer on record whitelists the permission. Specifically, if the permission is allowlisted the holder app can access external storage and the visual and aural media collections while if the permission is not allowlisted the holder app can only access to the visual and aural medial collections. Also the permission is immutably restricted meaning that the allowlist state can be specified only at install time and cannot change until the app is installed. For more details see android.content.pm.PackageInstaller.SessionParams#setWhitelistedRestrictedPermissions(Set).

Protection level: dangerous

Allows applications to connect to paired bluetooth devices.

Protection level: normal

vulnerabilityFindings.description: The implementation of checkServerTrusted() will probably trust any certificate chain. Usually, there is no need to override this method, except for the purpose of making sure that a specific server certificate is used. Make sure to call the default trust manager to get the minimum security guarantees provided by Android's basic X509 trust system. Not calling the default trust manager implementation may result in a worse security situation. From the array given by the first parameter, only the element with index zero can be used to perform pinning on an end entity certificate. The other elements of the array are not trustworthy, since the server may send any additional certificates unrelated to the chain as well, which are also present in the given array. Warning: Calling checkValidity is not secure, since it only checks system time against the date and time specified in the certificate. It does not test whether the certificate itself is trustworthy (i.e. signed by a trusted and valid certificate). Warning: The method getAcceptedIssuer cannot be used to pin CA certificates. Returned certificates are exempted from some X509 certificate checks.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation:
• If you do not want to pin a certificate, do not use a custom trust manager at all.
  • Be sure to call the default trust manager implementation, as it will perform a validation on the chain to check whether it is trustworthy.
  • If you want to pin certificates in an Android application targeting Android 6 and newer (recommended): Use a Network Security Configuration file to pin certificates instead.
  • If you want to pin an end entity certificate in an Android application targeting devices before Android 6: Check only the zero indexed element in the the certificate chain parameter array, since this is the end-entity certificate. Check whether this certificate is equal to the expected pinned certificate loaded from a trustworthy (local) source.
  • When you want to pin a certificate issuer: The X509TrustManagerExtension class can be used to retrieve a trustworthy chain based on the untrustworthy chain. It removes any certificates not matching to the chain. Use this method in checkServerTrusted to get a clean chain. CA pinning may be checked via the presence of certificates on this clean chain.
vulnerabilityFindings.title: SSL/TLS Vulnerability - Bad certificate chain checking

references.shortDescription: only the element with the index zero can be used to perform pinning on a end entity certificate

vulnerabilityFindings.description: The app uses reflection to access private methods or fields. Since private elements in libraries are assumed to not be accessed from the outside, they can change between different versions of the library without notice. Consequently, accessing such elements can hinder the maintainability of the project. Furthermore, directly accessing private elements can circumvent security checks of the public API. See this article in the SEI CERT Oracle Coding Standard for Java for further information.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation: Only use the public API of classes or libraries.
vulnerabilityFindings.title: Code calls private methods or fields through reflection

references.shortDescription: SEI CERT SEC05-J: Do not use reflection to increase accessibility of classes, methods, or fields

referenceGroup.name: SEI CERT Oracle Coding Standard for Java
referenceGroup.description: The SEI CERT Oracle Coding Standard for Java

vulnerabilityFindings.description: The app uses reflection to access private methods or fields. Since private elements in libraries are assumed to not be accessed from the outside, they can change between different versions of the library without notice. Consequently, accessing such elements can hinder the maintainability of the project. Furthermore, directly accessing private elements can circumvent security checks of the public API. See this article in the SEI CERT Oracle Coding Standard for Java for further information.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation: Only use the public API of classes or libraries.

vulnerabilityFindings.description:
One or more permissions have been declared as used in the manifest file, but do not seem to be actually used by the
application.
In case a vulnerability exists that allows an attacker to inject code, the attacker can also use the permissions which
are otherwise unused by the app.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation: Do not declare permissions with uses-permission which the application does not need to run.
vulnerabilityFindings.title: Unused permissions

references.shortDescription: The app only requests the minimum set of permissions necessary.

references.shortDescription: Applications must only request Use Permissions or grant Permissions that are required for execution purposes.

referenceGroup.name: Telekom requirements for Android applications
referenceGroup.description: The Telekom requirements for Android applications, available at the Telekom Homepage

vulnerabilityFindings.description:
An insecure cryptographic algorithm is used. Insecure cryptographic algorithms may enable attackers to get access to information,
which is supposed to be protected.
In case of encryption algorithms, this might include deciphering and tampering with the data.
In case of hashing algorithms, an attacker might be able to generate passwords, which deliver the same hash as a known value. Depending
on the system architecture, this can be used to get access to parts of the system, which are not supposed to be accessible.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation:
Use up-to-date cryptographic algorithms.
  • Symmetric encryption: An example for a cipher considered secure is AES/CBC/PKCS7Padding
  • Asymmetric encryption: An example for a cipher considered secure is RSA/NONE/PKCS1Padding. Use this cipher to encrypt a randomly generated symmetric cipher key.
vulnerabilityFindings.title: Insecure Crypto Algorithm

references.shortDescription: If authentication procedures are being used, authentication data must be encrypted with up-to-date, strong crypto-algorithms.

referenceGroup.name: CWE
referenceGroup.description: CWE™ is a community-developed list of common software security weaknesses. It serves as a common language, a measuring stick for software security tools, and as a baseline for weakness identification, mitigation, and prevention efforts.

vulnerabilityFindings.description:
The app uses cryptography to secure data, but does so using a hard-coded key. This renders
the encryption ineffective, because attackers can decompile the application and extract the key.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation:
Do not store hard coded cryptographic keys in the application. Static keys cannot be stored in a secure manner in client side applications.
  • Generate secure random keys locally on the device.
  • Perform encryption on a server. If the data can be sent to a dedicated server without privacy implications, encrypting on server side may be an option. Static keys may be securely saved on the server. Note that downloading a static key from a server is not considered secure, as an attacker can just do the same.
vulnerabilityFindings.title: Hard-coded Cryptographic Key

references.shortDescription: The app does not rely on symmetric cryptography with hardcoded keys as a sole method of encryption.

vulnerabilityFindings.description:
An insecure cryptography mode is used, such as ECB (Electronic Code Book). ECB is also often used as a default mode when no other
block cipher mode is specified.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation: Use a more secure cryptography mode, such as CBC (Cipher Block Chaining).
vulnerabilityFindings.title: Insecure Cryptography Mode

vulnerabilityFindings.description:
An unsafe combination of an insecure algorithm and a static initialization vector (IV) is being used.
The initialization vector is used to randomize cipher texts when the input is the same. When a static IV is used, the same inputs result
in the same ciphertext, at least in parts. As such, a new IV should be selected randomly before each use. The IV is considered public
information.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation: Do not use a static IV. Generate a random IV instead and store it along the ciphertext. It is not needed to keep the IV secret.
vulnerabilityFindings.title: Static Initialization Vector (IV)

vulnerabilityFindings.description:
The concept of permissions enables the user to check what kind of actions applications can perform. This application
                 contains a vulnerability which third party applications can exploit to trigger actions or get data, for which they would
                 need to have a specific permission for.
Due to the vulnerability, they can trigger these actions on behalf of the vulnerable app without needing to have the
permission. This can be used to trick the user into thinking that the app does not require this permission.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation: If the component is only supposed to be used by other apps of the same developer, the app should define a new permission with the protection level signature. Other apps by the developer can use this permission. in order to do this, they need to be signed with the same key as the application containing the content provider. This ensures that no other application can access the content provider unless it has been signed by the same developer. If the component is supposed to be used by any other app, be sure to use checkCallingPermission to check whether the other app invoking the component has the appropriate permission.
vulnerabilityFindings.title: Other applications may trigger permission guarded actions without permissions

vulnerabilityFindings.description: The app enables compression for an HTTP(s) connection.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation:
Do not enable HTTP compression when transferring sensitive data. Alternatively, if compression is required,
implement app-specific countermeasures such as CSRF protection to avoid request injections.
vulnerabilityFindings.title: HTTP Compression Renders App Vulnerable to BREACH Attack

vulnerabilityFindings.description: Some apps require the user to enter potential sensitive information into the app. By default, the used keyboard may save the information provided by the user for the use of suggestions. On Android, users may choose to install third party keyboard apps, which provide a keyboard to use for all apps. These custom keyboard apps may treat suggestion lists differently, such as send statistical information about it to the developer. Usually, claiming the field as a text field which contains a password in cleartext prevents such behavior. Note that there is also the TYPE_TEXT_FLAG_NO_SUGGESTIONS to disable suggestions on most keyboards. However, some custom keyboards do not honor this flag properly (SwiftKey for example).
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation:
• When sensitive data should be entered in a free text format: Set the input type to TYPE_TEXT_VARIATION_PASSWORD to disable suggestions. Although this flag is intended to be used for fields where the user enters a password (which can be visible), it also works for other input types of text.
  • When specific sensitive data should be entered: Android supports different input types, notably for entering names, phone numbers, E-Mail and postal addresses
vulnerabilityFindings.title: Keyboard may cache values for a sensitive field due to suggestion

additionalData.name: Reason
additionalData.data: When running under Android 6.0 Marshmallow (API level 23), cleartext traffic is allowed

vulnerabilityFindings.description: Starting with Android 6.0 Marshmallow, Android has introduced a feature intended to disallow Apps to use cleartext traffic. Apps can opt out of this security feature through its security configuration file. However, this option should only be used if cleartext communication is absolutely required. Otherwise, apps should always communicate via secure protocols such as TLS. Note that WebView does not honor this flag.
vulnerabilityFindings.mitigiation:
For security reasons, no cleartext traffic should be allowed in most cases. Exceptions to this rule are external sites that don't provide an encryption channel. These unsecure domains should be whitelisted explicitly while a secure channel should be expected for all other domains.
  • If cleartext traffic is generally not intended, set the android:usesCleartextTraffic attribute to false in the application element.
  • If cleartext traffic should be allowed for certain domains, a Network Security Configuration should be used. In order to use configuration file, specify in the Android manifest where the file is located. A network security configuration overrides the android:usesCleartextTraffic attribute.
vulnerabilityFindings.title: Cleartext traffic allowed
